channel.title: Ted Tschopp's AI News
channel.description: Latest AI News and Ratings from Ted Tschopp

item.title: AI Generated “Workslop” Is Destroying Productivity [ ! ]
item.description: The article introduces a term “Workslop” when employees use AI to produce content that masquerades as good work, but lacks the substance to meaningfully advance a given task. Such workslop causes wasted time, frustration, and low return on investment despite widespread adoption of AI tools. Our analysts emphasized this as an emerging problem that leaders can and must control: setting up vetting, quality processes, human review, etc. They saw it as essential because unchecked workslop undermines productivity, credibility, and effectiveness of AI deployments.

item.title: AI chips are getting hotter. A microfluidics breakthrough goes straight to the silicon to cool up to three times better. [ ~ ]
item.description: This report covers a hardware cooling innovation that could relieve performance bottlenecks in AI chips. While very cool from a technology perspective, our analysts judged its near‑term relevance to most AI strategy teams as modest.

item.title: Notion creates more intelligent workspaces with Claude [ ~ ]
item.description: The article demonstrates how Notion integrates Claude to shorten information search time and assist writing/QA workflows. Our analysts saw it more as a marketing showcase—interesting but not a must‑read for every AI leader.

item.title: How Intuit built custom financial LLMs that cut latency 50% [ ~ ]
item.description: This is a strong use case of engineering optimization (reducing latency, improving domain accuracy), but for many leaders it lacks enough business context. Our analysts appreciated it as a technical optimization, though not universally actionable.

item.title: The new org chart: Unlocking value with AI-native roles in the agentic era [ * ]
item.description: This article argues for reorganizing teams with roles tailored to AI agents (e.g. orchestration, governance) rather than retrofitting old structures. Our analysts saw division: while it’s forward‑looking and not yet broadly applicable, analysts believed it’s important to help leaders think ahead about evolving org structures in the AI era.

item.title: How Gen AI Could Transform Learning and Development [ ! ]
item.description: This article investigates how generative AI can reshape corporate learning by embedding personalization, prompting skills, and decision‑support into L&D. Our analysts flagged it as mission-critical because many leaders are now scrambling to build AI literacy and culture—and this article provides initial underpinnings for doing that.

item.title: How Nvidia Is Backstopping America’s AI Boom [ ! ]
item.description: The piece explores NVIDIA’s strategic investments—especially into OpenAI and infrastructure—and how those investments amplify its revenue generation and influence over the AI stack. Our analysts emphasized that this article is essential for anyone tracking AI’s geopolitical and economic dynamics, as it reveals how capital, control, and hardware are intertwining in real time.

item.title: Introducing LFM2‑2.6B: Redefining Efficiency in Language Models [ ~ ]
item.description: Liquid AI, an MIT-founded startup, introduced a 2.6B parameter convolutional model aimed at efficient edge deployment, beating competitor models of similar size in performance. Our analysts acknowledged the technical novelty but noted the lack of adoption, use cases, or business traction—leaving it as a niche interest rather than a strategic priority for AI leaders.

item.title: Build more powerful voice agents with the Gemini Live API [ * ]
item.description: Google’s new Gemini Live API enables developers to build real-time AI voice agents with low latency, emotional tone control, and context-rich conversation. Our analysts viewed this as an important evolution in multimodal AI, with implications for future chatbots and virtual assistants, and a sign that Google is regaining leadership in generative AI product innovation.

item.title: Transforming SAP Technical Documentation with GenAI: Accelerating knowledge generation for SAP Notes with Amazon Bedrock [ * ]
item.description: SAP has partnered with AWS to apply generative AI to the summarization and delivery of technical documentation, targeting mobile-first use cases and legacy enterprise systems. Our analysts found the detailed implementation—especially around RAG, evaluation, and unstructured data—to be valuable for AI leaders modernizing complex internal knowledge assets, despite a lack of ROI data.

item.title: Deutsche Bank delivers AI-powered financial research with DB Lumina [ * ]
item.description: Deutsche Bank’s DB Lumina integrates generative AI, RAG pipelines, and internal knowledge bases to assist analysts in generating financial research more efficiently and safely. Our analysts noted this as a well-architected and regulated example of AI in finance, though they held it back from Essential due to limited detail on business outcomes and adoption metrics.

item.title: Google’s Mixboard is an AI moodboard builder [ ! ]
item.description: Google has introduced Mixboard, a generative AI tool that enables users to create and manipulate visual concept boards from text prompts, signaling a shift toward visual-first communication. Our analysts highlighted its potential beyond marketing, emphasizing its relevance for communication across organizations and noting strong early user feedback and real-world utility for AI leaders.

item.title: AI Is Transforming Productivity, but Sales Remains a New Frontier [ ! ]
item.description: This article from Bain & Company explores how generative AI is reshaping sales by increasing time spent selling and highlighting over two dozen use cases across the customer journey. Our analysts emphasized that AI in sales is shifting from efficiency to growth, making it a critical area for AI leaders to engage with revenue-driving strategies.

item.title: CWM: An Open‑Weights LLM for Research on Code Generation with World Models [ ~ ]
item.description: Meta’s 32B open‑weights model trained on code + world models enables execution traces in environments (e.g. Docker). Our analysts found this valuable to the developer community, but less immediately relevant for strategy-level readers.

item.title: ENEOS Materials brings ChatGPT Enterprise to manufacturing [ ~ ]
item.description: A use case of ChatGPT in industrial operations in Japan, showing cross‑language support and internal applications. Our analysts liked it as a real-world example, though lacking strong economic detail.

item.title: Autoregressive‑to‑Diffusion Vision Language Models [ ~ ]
item.description: A technical paper proposing an efficient pipeline for going from vision to language via diffusion / autoregressive models. Our analysts viewed it as “nice algorithmic innovation” but not broadly disruptive for leadership priorities.

item.title: Measuring the performance of our models on real‑world tasks [ * ]
item.description: OpenAI introduces “GDPval,” a framework evaluating AI impact across 44 occupations via 1,320 specialized tasks. Our analysts considered it smart and useful for benchmarking value, though not yet critical for most AI leaders right now.

item.title: Building the Next Generation of Physical Agents with Gemini Robotics‑ER 1.5 [ * ]
item.description: Gemini Robotics‑ER 1.5 is the first open embodied reasoning model that lets robots perceive, plan, use tools, and act in complex physical environments. Our analysts weighed its significance (combining language models + physical planning) and discussed whether it should be essential and ultimately rated “important” because the domain of robotics still touches fewer AI leaders today but agreed that in the field of Robotics, this is essential news.

item.title: Introducing ChatGPT Pulse [ ! ]
item.description: This introduction marks a shift in ChatGPT’s role from reactive tool to proactive agent: Pulse conducts background research using your chat history, memory, and connected apps (e.g. calendar) and surfaces daily personalized visual cards. Our analysts saw this as a foundational change in human–AI interaction and a preview of what proactive digital intelligence might mean for both consumers and enterprises.

item.title: California's Newsom signs law requiring AI safety disclosures [ ~ ]
item.description: A new California law mandates transparency from companies building large-scale AI models, marking one of the first legislative moves in the U.S. focused on AI safety reporting. However, our analysts pointed out the lack of clear enforcement mechanisms and viewed it as largely symbolic — reinforcing the need for more robust and coordinated federal-level AI regulation to meaningfully shape AI ethics and safety standards.

item.title: DeepSeek-V3.2-Exp [ ~ ]
item.description: DeepSeek has released version 3.2 of its experimental large language model, highlighting optimizations in inference speed and support for advanced reasoning benchmarks. Our analysts noted the clever use of sparse attention techniques to lower computational cost while maintaining quality, but emphasized that its Chinese origin limits immediate relevance for AI leaders focused on enterprise adoption in Western markets.

item.title: Introducing parental controls [ ~ ]
item.description: OpenAI has launched parental control features for ChatGPT, allowing parents to manage access and tailor AI interactions for teens and kids using the app. Our analysts were skeptical about the real-world effectiveness of these controls, citing the general gap in AI literacy among parents and the ease with which teenagers can bypass restrictions — making this a socially meaningful update, but not directly relevant for AI leaders or enterprise applications.

item.title: GLM-4.6: Advanced Agentic, Reasoning and Coding Capabilities [ * ]
item.description: Zhipu AI's new GLM-4.6 model shows advances in agentic behavior, multi-step reasoning, and programming skills, positioning it as a strong open alternative to GPT-4. Our analysts noted that as one of China’s top three AI developers, Zhipu has produced a model that performs just below Claude 4.5 in coding benchmarks — making this a rising model to watch closely in the global LLM race.

item.title: How PropHero built an intelligent property investment advisor with continuous evaluation using Amazon Bedrock [ ! ]
item.description: PropHero demonstrates a practical application of AI in real estate by building a generative AI-driven advisor using Amazon Bedrock. Our analysts highlighted the thoughtful orchestration of a multi-agent system, the deliberate selection of foundation models per agent to optimize cost-performance, and the use of detailed evaluation metrics from Rajas — making this a textbook example of how to build and measure business value with generative AI.

item.title: Sora 2 is here [ ! ]
item.description: OpenAI has unveiled Sora 2, an upgraded version of its generative video model with dramatic improvements in motion accuracy, scene composition, and prompt handling. Our analysts agreed that the introduction of Cameos (letting users insert themselves or others into videos) and a new social platform, signal a shift toward consumer-grade AI video creation and sharing — making this a critical development for leaders watching the future of AI-driven content creation.

item.title: Microsoft retires AutoGen and debuts Agent Framework to unify and govern enterprise AI agents [ ~ ]
item.description: Microsoft’s new Agent Framework consolidates its agent tools into a more unified and secure environment, with features like task adherence and PII detection. Despite being a notable evolution, our analysts saw it as a rebranding effort and more relevant to existing Azure users than the broader AI community.

item.title: LFM2‑Audio‑1.5B from Liquid AI [ ~ ]
item.description: Liquid AI’s new audio model joins a growing family of open-source multimodal models but lacks detailed benchmarks or differentiators. The discussion concluded it’s a watchlist item rather than a near-term driver of AI innovation or adoption.

item.title: Apriel‑1.5‑15b‑Thinker – Mid training is all you need! [ ~ ]
item.description: ServiceNow’s new 15B parameter model performs well on reasoning tasks and introduces efficient mid-training techniques. However, our analysts found its value incremental in a saturated small model market, noting limited enterprise adoption so far and lack of distinctive application context.

item.title: The anatomy of a personal health agent [ ! ]
item.description: Google’s latest research showcases an AI Personal Health Agent that combines personal health data, symptoms, and diagnostics to offer tailored wellness insights. Though targeted at healthcare, our analysts viewed its multi-agent architecture as highly generalizable across industries, reinforcing the rise of domain-specific AI agent ecosystems.

item.title: Effective context engineering for AI agents [ ! ]
item.description: Anthropic outlines how to optimize AI agents by focusing on “context engineering” rather than just prompt design, improving coherence and performance in multi-agent systems. Our analysts emphasized this shift as foundational for enterprise AI, especially in workflows requiring task memory, inference layering, and state management.

item.title: Real AI Agents and Real Work [ ! ]
item.description: This article argues that AI agents have moved beyond task support into executing meaningful, standalone work—such as creating presentations or replicating academic research. Our analysts agreed it marks a critical inflection point in the AI landscape, with practical examples proving agents are now delivering tangible business outcomes.

item.title: IBM Granite 4.0: hyper-efficient, high performance hybrid models for enterprise [ ~ ]
item.description: IBM's new Granite 4.0 models leverage a hybrid Transformer-Mamba architecture for greater efficiency and extended context handling. Despite technical promise and enterprise positioning, our analysts noted performance gaps versus leaders like OpenAI and Anthropic, making this more of a product evolution than a market disruptor at present.

item.title: Tinker is a training API for developers [ ~ ]
item.description: Tinker, developed by Thinking Machines (founded by former OpenAI CTO Mira Murati), offers developers a managed API to fine-tune large language models with minimal infrastructure setup. Our analysts found it innovative but premature for enterprise use, citing unclear differentiation, data security risks, and pricing volatility.

item.title: What Happens When AI Sets Wages [ ~ ]
item.description: This HBR article investigates the growing use of AI to determine worker wages, touching on themes of fairness, transparency, and bias. While thought-provoking, our analysts agreed it remains largely editorial and narrowly scoped, with limited immediate impact for enterprise AI strategy.

item.title: The AI Application Spending Report: Where Startup Dollars Really Go [ ~ ]
item.description: This report from Andreessen Horowitz explores startup spending trends on AI vendors and tooling, offering insight into where early AI investments are flowing. Our analysts saw it as a snapshot with limited strategic utility, better suited for context on tool popularity than enterprise decision-making.

item.title: Hexagon Automates Manufacturing Standard Operating Procedures with AWS Generative AI [ * ]
item.description: This AWS case study showcases how Hexagon used generative AI to digitize SOPs, achieving over 90% automation accuracy in transforming manufacturing operating procedure documents. Our analysts found the technical architecture informative and forwardable, despite the lack of detailed business impact metrics or long-term maintenance discussion.

item.title: JPMorgan Chase's blueprint to become the world's first fully AI-powered megabank [ ! ]
item.description: JPMorgan is aiming to become the first fully AI-integrated megabank, applying generative AI across 250,000 employees with tools like secure chatbots and internal agents. Our analysts emphasized this as a rare example of CEO-led AI transformation at scale, making it a must-watch case for AI leaders, especially in regulated industries.

item.title: Training Agents Inside of Scalable World Models [ ~ ]
item.description: Dreamer4 proposes an imaginative training paradigm (learning a latent world model and simulating actions inside it). Our analysts agreed that it’s an exciting technical advance, but still early — not yet broadly relevant to AI leaders outside research or robotics.

item.title: With GPT‑5, Wrtn builds lifestyle AI for millions in Korea [ ~ ]
item.description: This is an interesting regional case of combining GPT‑5 with cultural/language adaptation, routing between small and large models, local slang and politeness training. Our analysts saw it as promising but light on depth—more anecdote than blueprint.

item.title: Developer laws in the AI era [ * ]
item.description: Bessemer’s piece presents eight laws for how developers and platforms should evolve in an agentic, AI‑augmented future—covering pricing, ownership of interfaces, transparency, etc. Our analysts saw this as strategic and timely for AI leaders and dev teams, noting it aligns with trends about how tooling is reshaping the notion of “developer.”

item.title: Rox accelerates sales productivity with AI agents powered by Amazon Bedrock [ * ]
item.description: This case study details how multi-agent orchestration embedded into a sales platform led to claimed 2× revenue increase per rep, 50% lift in productivity, 20% faster sales velocity. Our analysts liked the architecture and ROI narrative but flagged it as somewhat promotional and lacking names of real customers, which holds it back from being essential.

item.title: NBIM accelerates sovereign wealth management with enterprise‑wide AI transformation [ ! ]
item.description: This is a large‑scale, real-world deployment in a regulated context managing $1.7 trillion in assets over 9,000 companies—exactly the kind of high‑impact use case that demonstrates AI at enterprise scale. Our analysts compared it to the JP Morgan case and emphasized how NBIM scaled AI adoption via “ambassadors” and top‑down mandate, underscoring the cultural as well as technical shift needed.

item.title: Understanding the 4 Main Approaches to LLM Evaluation [ ! ]
item.description: This article lays out a structured taxonomy of evaluation methods for large language models—benchmarks, judges, verifiers, and runtime evaluation—which is foundational for any AI team building or adopting LLMs. Our analysts agreed that article’s structured framing is critical for AI leaders to ask the right evaluation questions.

item.title: Front-Loading Reasoning: The Synergy between Pretraining and Post-Training Data [ ~ ]
item.description: The paper argues for injecting diverse reasoning examples during pretraining and focusing on high‑quality reasoning tasks in fine tuning. Our analysts panel found it intellectually worthwhile, but more relevant to researchers than applied AI practitioners right now.

item.title: State of Software 2025 [ ~ ]
item.description: This report delivers interesting metrics and trends across software markets in 2025. Our analysts considered it worthwhile for investors or tech watchers — but less immediately actionable for AI leaders.

item.title: Converting inbound leads into customers at OpenAI [ * ]
item.description: This is a useful case study of how OpenAI used a conversational assistant to personalize inbound lead interactions and improve conversions. Our analysts noted strong results in accuracy increase, though they wished the article gave more of how it was built and business results that were achieved.

item.title: Introducing CodeMender: an AI agent for code security [ * ]
item.description: CodeMender from Google DeepMind aims to detect and repair code vulnerabilities automatically, acting both proactively and reactively. Our analysts appreciated the ambition but noted it’s still research‑stage and raised concerns about side effects of automated fixes in complex systems.

item.title: Deloitte issues refund for error-ridden Australian government report that used AI [ ! ]
item.description: Deloitte’s refund underscores real risks in relying on AI without rigorous validation — a cautionary tale for any AI initiative. Our analyst team viewed it as a strong reminder to have Ai-in-the-loop and human‑in‑the‑loop safeguards, and to treat AI outputs with skepticism and continued oversight.

item.title: Introducing apps in ChatGPT and the new Apps SDK [ ! ]
item.description: This announcement lets developers embed or connect apps directly into ChatGPT, turning ChatGPT into a platform/operating system rather than just a chatbot. Our analysts emphasized that this is strategically significant — positioning OpenAI as a one-stop interface that threatens search and browser incumbents.

item.title: Introducing AgentKit [ ! ]
item.description: AgentKit offers a graphical, drag‑and‑drop way to build conversational agents, along with tools like evaluation kits, registries, and guardrails. Our analysts flagged this as a hugely important strategic step for OpenAI to compete with agent platforms, and noted its significance because it comes directly from OpenAI.
